posts.name: Michael Tucker
posts.cooked:
We at Gull Lake Area Robotics in Richland MI have conjured up a 54A external load that can run in parallel with the West Mountain Radio Computer Battery Analyzer. The box we built has a composite 60A test load, costs less than $225.00, and reduces the 75-minute test cycle to less than 15 minutes.

Everyone struggles with battery confidence. We are sharing this work because we believe this can benefit other teams.

We went through five design iterations on our journey to the production result. The 11-page PDF can be viewed and downloaded at this link .

Cheers everyone, and here’s to a great Reefscape season!

Mike T, Electrical Sub-Team Mentor 4381 - Twisted Devils 4422 - Twisted Angels

This is fantastic!  We even discussed getting a second tester due to the time investment for testing batteries.  With 20 new batteries each season (2 teams) and selectively testing previous season batteries, it takes almost the entire off-season to get it done. I know what my electrical subteam is doing next week…lol. Thank you for the comprehensive write-up!

posts.name: Michael Tucker
posts.cooked:
Excellent.

Let me know how the ELT works for your team.
Can you post a picture of what it looks like with everything hooked up and ready to test?  A picture of the final tray configuration would be great as well!

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked: That is a nice setup you have created. How consistent are the results when they are repeated with a battery that is fully charged using the same charger?

posts.name: Michael Tucker
posts.cooked:
This is the most recent test of a brand new Andy Mark battery that I did last week. The dates look confusing, but the two most recent tests that ran nearly 9-minutes stacked nicely upon each other.

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked: In the V5 section of your document, it states “Increase the CBA current test to 5.4A to obtain the 60A load.” Does the CBA still measure 5.4A even though the total load current is 60A? Do you scale the mAh measurement from the CBA to account for the current flowing through the external resistors?

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
ummm…is this an initial setup picture?

Are these terminals actually crimped? asking because they look hardly deformed. Perhaps a hammer-style crimp from the underside?

Did you solder them internally that we cannot see?

image 964×1194 78.9 KB

image 964×1194 78.9 KB

image 964×1194 78.9 KB
In the write-up, they mentioned filling them with solder.

posts.name: Michael Tucker
posts.cooked: I potted solder into the 4 AWG terminals with a 50% fill, then I inserted the wires and let everything cool to a solid state. I did that for the 1/4" lugs on the Main breaker and the Anderson SB120 terminals.

posts.name: Michael Tucker
posts.cooked:
Yes, and No. Yes, the 9 2 Ohm resistors in parallel create a composite 54 Amp load. No in that the CBA doesn’t know about the external load.

The two fans carry a 0.2 amp load each as does the automotive relay.

In order to use the CBA with this there has to have some sort of internal current draw at this device. 5.4A plus 0.6 A plus 54 Amps gets everything rounded up to 60A.

posts.name: Michael Tucker
posts.cooked:
Elaborating here. The CBA only knows it’s testing a battery at 5.4A. It’s a parallel device connected to the 54A load amplifier. As such, you can’t rely on the right side table that calculates the battery capacity.

Instead, what you are looking for in the graph is a battery that can sustain a 60A draw for at least 7 minutes.

This and with consideration of the measured battery internal resistance being under 0.019 Ohms, is what I would rate as a competition ready battery.
